title: Newcastle 'encourage Joelinton to bring his family over to England'
text:
Newcastle are to 'encourage' Joelinton to bring some of his family over to England to help him settle as Steve Bruce looks to find a solution to the striker's poor start to life in the north east.

The Telegraph report Bruce already has the Brazilian striker in extra training in a bid to become more used to the physical demands of the Premier League.

But it also appears a conscious effort is being made to help the club's £40million record signing settle off the pitch as Bruce aims to unlock the player's potential with his side desperately seeking a goalscorer.

Newcastle are reportedly encouraging Joelinton to have family in England to help him settle

Joelinton has been learning English and has been advised to stay close to Andy Carroll when at the training ground, with the English striker said to be acting as a mentor for his team-mate.

There has been an acknowledgement that the former Hoffenheim striker has been given little support in matches and has often been left to battle with two defenders, often with little joy.

It appears the club feel having family with him in England could ease his integration in the run-up to Christmas given he lives alone in an apartment.

The uncapped Brazilian is partaking in extra training to adapt to the physicality in England

Having had just 10 shots on target so far this season, Joelinton has one goal to his name in a Newcastle shirt.

The club are sat 17th after 10 games, one point ahead of the relegation zone following the 1-1 draw with Wolves at the weekend.

Bruce has no worries about Joelinton's rough start to life in England and has backed the club's No 9 to come good.

'He is only young and he has to find his feet,' he said after the draw with Wolves.

'He's only 23. And I'm sure the longer it goes it will get better.

'If you are going to wear the number 9 shirt he's got to chip in with a few goals. He can only improve.'
description: Newcastle are to 'encourage' Joelinton (left) to bring some of his family over to England to help him settle as Steve Bruce looks to find a solution to the striker's poor start to life in the north east.
